isis.stitle: SINGLE REDUCTION, TANDEM AXLES: SPICER J400-S, W460-S - ASSEMBLE - PINION ASSEMBLY

step1.para: Press inner pinion bearing cone onto the pinion gear ( Figure 94).

figure.caption: Figure 93. Press Inner Pinion Bearing Cone onto Pinion Gear

step1.para: Press roller bearing onto the pinion gear ( Figure 95).

figure.caption: Figure 94. Press Roller Bearing onto Pinion Gear

step1.para: Stake roller bearing in nine places, using a staking tool ( Figure 96).

figure.caption: Figure 95. Stake Roller Bearing in Nine Places

note.para: Make sure all cage bores are free of nicks, dirt, or any contamination.

step1.para: Install inner pinion bearing cup into pinion cage ( Figure 97).

figure.caption: Figure 96. Install Inner Pinion Bearing Cup into Pinion Cage

step1.para: Install outer pinion bearing cup into pinion cage ( Figure 98).

figure.caption: Figure 97. Install Outer Pinion Bearing Cup into Pinion Cage

step1.para: Use a feeler gauge or shim stock (.0015 approx.) to ensure bearing cups are completely seated in bearing bores. This is necessary for proper pinion position ( Figure 99).

figure.caption: Figure 98. Use Feeler Gauge to Ensure Bearing Cups are Completely Seated

step1.para: Place selective preload spacer, that was removed during disassembly, onto pinion ( Figure 100).

figure.caption: Figure 99. Place Selective Preload Spacer onto Pinion

step1.para: Place pinion cage onto pinion gear inner bearing ( Figure 101).

figure.caption: Figure 100. Place Pinion Cage onto Pinion Gear Inner Bearing

step1.para: Install outer pinion bearing cone onto pinion ( Figure 102).

figure.caption: Figure 101. Install Outer Pinion Bearing Cone onto Pinion

step1.para: Inspect rear carrier end yoke seal surface for grooves caused by lip of seal. If grooves can be detected with fingernail, it should be replaced.

Install gear onto pinion of forward carrier. Tighten castellated nut to 600 ft-lbs. (813 Nm). If hole in pinion does not align with slots in nut, tighten nut until they are aligned. Do not install roll pin at this time ( Figure 103).

note.para: On rear carriers, install end yoke onto pinion without seal to allow proper setting of bearing preload. Tighten pinion nut to 900 to 1200 ft-lbs. (1220 to 1627 Nm).
Pinion cage should be rotated while tightening pinion nut to seat and align the pinion bearings.
There are two methods of measuring pinion bearing preload and both are acceptable. Mechanic's preference and available tools determine which method will be used.

step1.para: To measure preload with the spring scale, clamp the end yoke horizontally in a soft-jawed vise. Attach one end of cord to a bolt hole in the pinion cage, wrap cord around pinion cage and attach the other end of cord to the spring scale. Rotate pinion cage by pulling scale. Read scale during fourth revolution. Scale reading must be between 3 and 9 lbs. (1.4 and 4.0 kg) ( Figure 104).

figure.caption: Figure 103. Measure Preload With Spring Scale

step1.para: To measure preload with the inch pound torque wrench, assemble pinion cage into the carrier housing and install two mounting bolts to anchor the unit. Rotate pinion gear with inch pound torque wrench as shown in Figure 105. Torque measurement will be taken during fourth revolution and must be between 10 and 30 in-lbs. (1.1 and 3.4 Nm) without pinion seal (rear).

figure.caption: Figure 104. Measure Preload With Inch Pound Torque Wrench

note.para: When preload reading does not fall within allowable limits, bearing load can be increased by using a thinner spacer or decreased by using a thicker spacer.

.001 inch (.025 mm) change in preload spacer thickness changes scale reading by approximately 10 lbs. .001 change in preload spacer will change torque to rotate by approximately 30 in-lbs. (3.4 Nm). This is only a guide. Individual carriers may vary slightly. Refer to SPECIFICATIONS for available spacers.
Closer adjustment can be made by sanding next thicker spacer to desired thickness using emery cloth on a flat surface.
Wash spacer thoroughly of emery cuttings before installing on pinion.

step1.para: After proper preload is achieved, install new roll pin into forward carrier pinion. If roll pin cannot be installed, tighten pinion nut until roll pin can be installed. Pinion gear and cage assembly are now ready to be installed into the carrier housing ( Figure 106).

figure.caption: Figure 105. Install New Roll Pin into Forward Carrier Pinion

step1.para: After proper preload is achieved on rear carriers, remove end yoke and install new seal. Apply a small amount of light grease on lip of sealing surface prior to installation.

Clean and dry threads on pinion. Coat threads with Loctite #680 (green) adhesive compound or its equivalent. Install end yoke, washer, and new prevailing torque pinion nut. Tighten nut to 900 to 1200 ft-lbs. (1220 to 1627 Nm) ( Figure 107).

figure.caption: Figure 106. Tighten Prevailing Torque Pinion Nut
